name: Sugar Maple
description: A large deciduous tree known for its spectacular fall foliage and sap used to make maple syrup. The sugar maple is the state tree of Vermont, West Virginia, Wisconsin, and New York.
uses: Lumber for furniture and flooring; Maple syrup production; Ornamental shade tree; Wood for musical instruments
wildlife: Seeds eaten by birds and small mammals

name: Red Maple
description: One of the most common trees in eastern North America, valued for its brilliant red fall color and adaptability to various soil conditions.
uses: Ornamental landscaping; Lumber for furniture; Urban street tree; Firewood
wildlife: Flowers provide early nectar for bees

name: Eastern White Pine
description: The tallest tree in eastern North America, featuring soft, flexible needles in bundles of five. Historically important for ship masts and lumber.
uses: Softwood lumber; Construction timber; Woodworking; Christmas trees
wildlife: Seeds eaten by birds and squirrels

name: Ponderosa Pine
description: A massive western pine with distinctive orange-red bark plates and long needles. Known for its vanilla-scented bark and drought tolerance.
uses: Lumber for construction; Telephone poles; Railroad ties; Firewood
wildlife: Important for cavity-nesting birds

name: White Oak
description: A majestic hardwood tree with rounded lobes on leaves, producing sweet acorns. The white oak is prized for its strong, durable wood and is the state tree of Illinois, Connecticut, and Maryland.
uses: Premium furniture wood; Whiskey barrel construction; Flooring; Shipbuilding
wildlife: Acorns are prime food for deer, turkeys, and squirrels

name: Red Oak
description: A fast-growing oak with pointed leaf lobes and bitter acorns. Widely planted as a street and shade tree due to its tolerance of urban conditions.
uses: Lumber for furniture and cabinets; Flooring; Interior trim; Firewood
wildlife: Acorns support diverse wildlife

name: Black Walnut
description: A valuable hardwood tree producing edible nuts and one of the most expensive native hardwoods. The tree releases juglone, which inhibits growth of some nearby plants.
uses: Premium furniture and veneer; Gunstocks; Edible nuts; Natural wood dye
wildlife: Nuts eaten by squirrels

name: Shagbark Hickory
description: Named for its distinctive shaggy bark that peels in large strips. Produces sweet, edible nuts and extremely hard, shock-resistant wood.
uses: Tool handles and axe handles; Smoking meat; Edible nuts; Firewood - excellent heat
wildlife: Nuts highly valuable for wildlife

name: American Chestnut
description: Once dominant in eastern forests, nearly wiped out by chestnut blight in early 1900s. Efforts underway to breed blight-resistant varieties.
uses: Rot-resistant lumber (historical); Edible nuts; Tannin extraction; Restoration projects
wildlife: Nuts were crucial food source for wildlife

name: American Elm
description: An iconic vase-shaped tree that once lined streets across America. Dutch elm disease has devastated populations, but disease-resistant cultivars are being developed.
uses: Historic street tree; Shade tree; Lumber for furniture; Basket making
wildlife: Seeds eaten by birds and small mammals

name: Bald Cypress
description: A deciduous conifer that thrives in swamps and wet areas. Develops distinctive 'knees' (pneumatophores) when growing in water.
uses: Rot-resistant lumber; Landscaping near water; Mulch from shredded bark; Furniture
wildlife: Seeds eaten by waterfowl

name: Douglas Fir
description: Not a true fir, but one of the most important timber trees in North America. Can live over 500 years and reach enormous sizes.
uses: Construction lumber; Plywood; Christmas trees; Flooring and veneers
wildlife: Seeds important for birds and small mammals

name: American Beech
description: Smooth gray bark makes this tree distinctive. Holds its copper-colored dead leaves through winter, providing year-round interest.
uses: Hardwood flooring; Furniture; Veneer; Firewood
wildlife: Beechnuts feed many species

name: Black Cherry
description: Valued for its beautiful reddish-brown wood used in fine furniture. Produces small black cherries eaten by wildlife but bitter to humans.
uses: Premium furniture wood; Cabinets; Musical instruments; Flavoring extract from bark
wildlife: Cherries important food for birds

name: Quaking Aspen
description: The most widely distributed tree in North America. Leaves tremble in the slightest breeze due to flattened petioles. Forms large clonal colonies.
uses: Pulpwood for paper; Oriented strand board (OSB); Matchsticks; Erosion control
wildlife: Bark important food for elk and deer in winter

name: Sweetgum
description: Known for star-shaped leaves and spiky seed balls. Excellent fall color, but the seed balls can be a maintenance issue.
uses: Lumber for furniture and cabinets; Veneer; Plywood; Storax resin for perfumes
wildlife: Seeds eaten by birds and squirrels

name: Tulip Tree
description: Also called Yellow Poplar, one of the tallest eastern hardwoods. Tulip-shaped flowers appear in spring, and leaves are distinctively shaped.
uses: Lumber for furniture; Cabinets and millwork; Pulpwood; Honey production from flowers
wildlife: Seeds eaten by birds and small mammals

name: Flowering Dogwood
description: A small ornamental tree with showy spring flowers (actually bracts). State tree of Virginia and Missouri. Provides excellent fall color and winter berries.
uses: Ornamental landscaping; Tool handles (historically); Small woodworking projects; Wildlife plantings
wildlife: Berries eaten by many bird species

name: Eastern Redcedar
description: Actually a juniper, not a cedar. Dense wood is aromatic and naturally moth-repellent. Pioneer species often first to colonize fields.
uses: Cedar chests and closet lining; Pencils; Fence posts; Essential oil
wildlife: Berries important winter food for birds

name: Bigleaf Maple
description: The largest maple in North America with leaves up to 12 inches across. Pacific Northwest native valued for figured wood grain.
uses: Figured wood for guitars and furniture; Veneer; Syrup production (less than sugar maple); Flooring
wildlife: Seeds eaten by birds and small mammals
